data.title: NVDA is sometimes unable to gain focus

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
NVDA is (quite infrequently) unable to focus on the control with keyboard focus in VS code when alt tabbing into it from another application. What fixes it is pressing alt+f to bring upu the file menu, then pressing escape. 

When this occurs, Code is completely unuseable with NVDA (pressing tab and arrow keys doesn't do anything)

data.title: Use WSL Git as integrated VSCode Git
data.body:
I would like to use WSL Git with VSCode instead of Git for Windows to avoid multiple Git installations.

WSL is my default terminal in VSCode, but the integrated Git in VSCode doesn't work with WSL out of the box. I tried to emulate the `git.exe` comportement with a simple bat file redirecting git commands in WSL. It works nicely in CMD, but not as the integrated Git in VSCode...

**settings.json**:
```json
{
    "git.path": "D:\\tools\\git.bat",
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\Sysnative\\bash.exe"
}
```

**git.bat**:
```bat
@echo off
bash -c 'git %*'
```

Any idea to make VSCode integrated Git working with WSL Git ?

VSCode: 1.13.0
Windows: 10.15063.296
WSL: ubuntu 16.04
Git in WSL: 2.7.4

data.title: Git credential cache doesn't work with integrated task terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: Debian Jessie

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable credential cache globally for git
2. Run git pull inside a bash script
3. Run that task more than one time, type password of remote git
Normally, after the first time, you shouldn't need to type the password again, but unfortunately, the credential cache doesn't seem to work with the integrated terminal when running it in scripts. Interestingly it though works with the native linux terminal (bash)

Thanks for your time!

data.title: Feature requests: Better naming for projects + Scoped extensions
data.body:
Hello VsCode Team!
Great work on this IDE. I love it, and I use it on all my platforms (Windows, Linux, MacOS).
I'd like to suggest some improvements for the IDE itself

# 1: Better naming for projects
99% of the time I work on projects involving .NET Core and Angular2+. For simplicity, I use at least 2 instance of VSCode, one for the c# project, and one for the angular (typescript). This is useful because I have 2 integrated terminals, I can visually switch projects with alt+tab, and potentially use my other monitors to have side-by-side checking. 
But, because in VSCode the working folder names the program's window title, it's often confusing. As extra proof, look at this screenshot:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6514323/26965589-bcd86b3c-4cf6-11e7-8db5-a710ac0bd09a.png)
the contextual menu on the taskbar icon can be really confusing: which "src" (angular project) folder is related to the project I'm working on the other window? (In the picture above, PLV is the .net core project, and the first "src" folder is the angular project related).

Would be cool to add (for example) an optional entry on settings.json in the .vscode folder, to name my project, name that will be reflected on contextual menus and VSCode's window title.

# 2: Scoped extensions
In my setup I may have a relevant number of extension installed. 
Recall the previous example: 2 instances of VSCode with different target runtimes. 
The c# project may need the Omnisharp extension and few others, whereas the angular one may need multiple extensions related to typescript, css/scss, angular snippets, formatters/beautifiers and so on.

Why not use the settings.json to enable (or disable, what better suits you guys) per-project extensions? This will impact the overall memory usage, and declutter the VSCode window itself.

Thank you,
Valerio

data.title: Option to autohide minimap when in Split Editor view

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
* VSCode Version: 1.13.0
* OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. `"editor.minimap.enabled": true`

Idea: There should be an option when user is in Split Editor the minimap will be hidden automatically.
Especially on smaller resolutions the minimap takes too much space when working in Split Editor view.
For example something like this: `"editor.minimap.spliteditorhide": true`

data.title: [cpp] Coloring options for code disabled via preprocessor directives [Preprocessor] [UI]

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Currently code within preprocessor directives and code outside it has no difference in visual style. This can result in less readable code as it's hard to tell what is currently relevant. Intellisense doesn't work properly in disabled parts either, so having it shown with ordinary colors doesn't help.

While changing it all into one color (e.g. like green, comment-like, in MonoDevelop with Unity) is one option, maybe having a different background color is another possibility too.

```
20960: __readFile: e:\mywork\workflow\feb\node_modules\inquirer\lib\ui\prompt.js
```

and error stack:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6769037/26963469-439b5788-4d1f-11e7-9aa9-b84447c2704f.png)

I try

all of them are work fine.

trace below:

sorry, I cant provide the source code because it is an internal module.

I don't want to reinstall vsc, anything could help, please?

data.title: Request the feature: "editor.lineHighlightForeground".

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
### Request the feature:  "editor.lineHighlightForeground"  
Sometimes it is necessary to change the style colour of the selected text, after **"editor.lineHighlightBackground".**  
An example:  
`"editor.lineHighlightBackground": "#000", "editor.lineHighlightForeground": "#fff"`.  
Cheers.

data.title: Bad text colors in terminal in Solarized Dark theme (regression)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.4.2|
|gitignore|codezombiech|0.5.0|
|bracket-pair-colorizer|CoenraadS|0.10.4|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.4|
|Ionide-fsharp|Ionide|2.26.1|
|hoogle-vscode|jcanero|0.0.4|
|tabsanity|jedmao|0.0.9|
|language-haskell|justusadam|2.2.0|
|docomment|k--kato|0.0.15|
|vscode-rust|kalitaalexey|0.3.14|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.61|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.10.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|1.2.1|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|2.0.8|
|java|redhat|0.5.0|
|haskero|Vans|1.3.1|
|gitblame|waderyan|1.11.2|
|change-case|wmaurer|1.0.0|;


---

The colors in the integrated terminal with the Solarized Dark theme changed in the update to 1.13, and they're now difficult to read.

In native terminal (Powershell):

![captugoodre](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19817004/26961394-1babbb5a-4c93-11e7-9ced-d18fa1598b06.PNG)

In VS Code terminal:

![capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19817004/26961400-25db4352-4c93-11e7-9be3-870494d63daf.PNG)

The other themes still have the yellow and grey scheme that Powershell uses, which is also what the Solarized Dark theme used to use before 1.13. The Solarized Light theme also has different colors than the native terminal and the other themes, but those at least are readable.

data.title: Dotnet build task fails when command is specified at task level
data.body:
When specifying the `dotnet` command at the task level, running the task fails with:

>No executable found matching command "dotnet-/Users/Ben.Foster/Source/checkout-gateway/src/Gateway.Api/Gateway.Api.csproj"

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4

```
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "runner": "terminal",
    "showOutput": "always",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "suppressTaskName": true,
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "dotnet: build",
            "command": "dotnet",
            "args": [
                "${workspaceRoot}/src/Gateway.Api/Gateway.Api.csproj"
            ],
            "showOutput": "silent",
            "problemMatcher": ["$msCompile"]
        },
        {
            "command": "${workspaceRoot}/build.sh",
            "taskName": "Cake: build",
            "args": [
                "--target",
                "__Build",
                "--configuration",
                "Debug"
            ],
            "isBuildCommand": true
        },
        {
            "command": "${workspaceRoot}/build.sh",
            "taskName": "Cake: test",
            "args": [
                "--target",
                "__Test",
                "--configuration",
                "Debug"
            ],
            "isTestCommand": true
        }
    ]
}
```
